title: Extinction Rebellion deny damaging world famous White Horse monument
text:
Extinction Rebellion’s activism with the Alton Barnes White Horse has been criticised

(Picture: Apex News)

Members of a local community have been angered by Extinction Rebellion (XR) putting its logo on a world famous monument.

The Alton Barnes White Horse in Wiltshire had the environmental group’s symbol placed on it on Sunday, just weeks after a massive restoration operation led by local children.

Local XR activists used dark cloth to create the symbol before putting it on the fragile chalk horse.

The move angered locals, including school children who, with the help of the RAF, spearheaded a huge restoration project on the Pewsey Vale horse in August.

XR representatives deny they did any damage.

Around 46 tonnes of pristine chalk were laid on the monument two months ago after Molly Sutherland, 11, was helped by dad Rob to work on the restoration.

One resident called the action ‘a wanton act of vandalism’ (Picture: APEX)

At the time, Molly said: ‘It’s amazing how many people have come to help.

Advertisement

‘There were people from France, Sweden, Hong Kong, the United States of America and Ireland.’

Now her dad says his daughter and other children were saddened by the stunt, which came ahead of two weeks of activism planned by the group across the world, which began today.

Mr Sutherland said: ‘The children are all aware of the issues around climate and want to make it better.

‘But they can’t comprehend why the white horse was chosen for this.

‘Hundreds of people helped re chalk it in August.

‘This is not a good way for XR to publicise their cause.’

School children and volunteers restored the site in August (Picture: APEX)

An RAF helicopter delivered bags of chalk to the decaying monument (Picture: APEX)

But local activists have hit back at claims that they damaged the monument.

A spokesman for The Vale of Pewsey XR group said on Sunday: ‘We protested against government inaction on climate change by making the XR logo, an hourglass, out of old clothes, on the Alton Barnes White Horse.

‘All fabric and clothes forming the logo will be collected soon and recycled – leaving no trace.’

The spokesman added: ‘(The logo is) an hourglass, the symbol used by XR to draw attention to the very real fact that time is rapidly running out for us to mitigate against the catastrophic effects of climate change.

Extinction Rebellion activists marry during protest on Westminster Bridge

‘We believe it is vital to deliver this message as urgently and as visibly as possible.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘This was by no means an illegal act.

‘We did not vandalise nor deface what is a beautiful chalk monument on the soil of our local community.

‘We too love the White Horse, and it is because of that love that we chose to do it.

‘We know that local children and their parents worked very hard to re-chalk the horse, and it looks absolutely pristine.’

They added that before undertaking the action, they spoke to someone involved with the re-chalking initiative and they were ‘reportedly fine with the idea as long as it left no trace’.

But another local, Graham Newland, said: ‘This is a wanton act of vandalism.

‘Besides disrespecting the children who they claim to act for, and angering them and the community who lovingly restored this fragile precious chalk environment, these so called protectors of the planet have done their bit to damage it.’

Mr Newland claimed that the chalk was ‘poisoned’ because of their action, calling the local activists ‘misguided vandals’.
